questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

 

The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 700 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it, even though it occurs continually in all living humans. It is about 700 mL/day or 50 mL/hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal insensible water loss is approximately 50 mL/hour, resulting from evaporation through the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 0.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRCP

 

Given the patient's presentation of multiple gallstones, an enlarged bile duct diameter, and elevated liver enzymes, there is a high suspicion of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct). An MRCP is the most appropriate initial investigation to visualize and confirm the presence of common bile duct stones without subjecting the patient to an invasive procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an invasive procedure that allows both the visualization and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct abnormalities. While it can be used to diagnose and treat choledocholithiasis, it is generally reserved for therapeutic interventions after the diagnosis has been established, given the risks associated with the procedure.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound: This technique can be very sensitive for detecting common bile duct stones and other biliary pathologies. However, in the context of a patient with an enlarged bile duct and elevated liver enzymes suggestive of choledocholithiasis, MRCP would be the preferred initial diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While the patient may ultimately require a cholecystectomy, especially if the gallstones are the cause of her symptoms, it's crucial to first assess and manage any potential common bile duct stones. Directly proceeding to cholecystectomy without addressing potential common bile duct stones could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has recently undergone total thyroidectomy for a thyroid mass. The histopathological examination shows papillary thyroid cancer. What would be the further management of this patient?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radioiodine scan

 

After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, the usual next step is a Radioiodine scan to detect any remaining thyroid tissue and potential metastasis. Based on the findings, further therapeutic radioactive iodine might be administered. Regular follow-up, including blood tests and imaging studies, will be necessary to monitor for any recurrence or metastasis.

 

Radioiodine scan (also known as I-123 or RAI scan) is often used post-thyroidectomy to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease. This aids in planning for subsequent radioactive iodine therapy to ablate residual tissue or treat metastatic disease. The patient is usually given a dose of radioactive iodine, which is taken up by any remaining thyroid cells, and then imaging is done to determine the distribution of the radioactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiation: Incorrect in the majority of cases. External beam radiation therapy is not typically the first line of treatment for papillary thyroid cancer. It might be considered in rare situations, such as for certain anaplastic thyroid cancers or when the cancer is very aggressive, doesn't take up iodine, and other treatments haven't worked.

 

Option C. Conservative management: Incorrect. Simply monitoring without further treatment is not the standard of care for papillary thyroid cancer after surgery, especially when the cancer is of significant size, shows aggressive features, or has spread to lymph nodes or distant sites. Typically, the patient will undergo some form of adjuvant therapy or monitoring, often starting with a radioiodine scan.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy: Incorrect for early and most intermediate stages. Chemotherapy isn't a standard treatment for most thyroid cancers. However, it might be recommended for people who don't respond to standard treatments and for certain types of aggressive thyroid cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, a radioiodine scan is typically used to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastatic disease, guiding further therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: Post-translational modification common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subunit aggregation

 

Post-translational modifications occur after the synthesis of a protein and are crucial for the protein to attain its functional form. Subunit aggregation is a process that involves the assembly of multiple protein subunits to form a functional complex. This process is common to several proteins, including collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin:

 

  • Collagen forms a triple helix structure by aggregating three polypeptide chains.
  • Hemoglobin is composed of two alpha and two beta globin chains that come together to form a functional protein capable of oxygen transport.
  • Immunoglobulins are composed of heavy and light chains that must aggregate to form the functional antibody.

 

Thus, the common post-translational modification among these proteins is subunit aggregation, where individual protein subunits come together to create a functional unit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splicing: This is a post-transcriptional modification that occurs at the RNA level, not at the protein level. It involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA and is not related to post-translational modifications.

 

Option B. Gene editing: Gene editing involves altering the DNA sequence, which occurs before transcription and translation. It is not a post-translational modification and does not pertain to protein processing.

 

Option D. Hydroxylation: Hydroxylation is a post-translational modification that specifically applies to collagen. It involves the addition of hydroxyl groups to proline and lysine residues, a process that requires vitamin C. However, hydroxylation is not a common modification across collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulins, which makes it an incorrect answer in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subunit aggregation is a post-translational modification common to collagen, hemoglobin, and immunoglobulin, where multiple protein subunits assemble to form a functional protein complex.

questions.text: Which staging is related to JNA? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radkowski

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that typically affects adolescent males. The staging system specifically related to JNA is the Radkowski staging system. This system helps to classify the extent of the tumor based on its location and spread:

 

  • Stage I: Tumor confined to the nasopharynx, nasal cavity, and may involve the paranasal sinuses.
  • Stage II: Tumor extends into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Stage III: Tumor invades the infratemporal fossa.
  • Stage IV: Tumor extends to the intracranial space, including the foramen magnum.

 

The Radkowski staging system helps in determining the surgical approach and prognosis for patients with JNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for various carcinomas, especially solid tumors like those in breast cancer, lung cancer, etc. It stands for Tumor, Node, Metastasis.

 

Option B. Ann Arbor: The Ann Arbor staging system is used for lymphomas, particularly Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.

 

Option D. Dukes: The Dukes staging system is used for colorectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Radkowski staging system is specifically used for staging Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), assessing its extent and guiding treatment options.

choices.text: Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition.
In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.
Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source.
Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about postmortem changes? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts. In drowning, the body floats with face down, buttocks up, legs and arms hanging down in front of the body as shown below:

 

 

Hence, in drowning the postmortem staining occurs over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition: Greenish discoloration after death occurs due to sulfmethemoglobin.

 

Earliest external sign of decomposition: greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

 

Earliest internal sign of putrefaction: reddish brown discoloration of aorta followed by greenish discoloration of undersurface of liver.

 

Option C. Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source: Adipocere formation requires presence of moisture, hence found in bodies recovered from water.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles: Cadaveric spasm is the localized sustained contraction of a specific set of muscles which were used profusely just before death. There is no primary relaxation phase and these muscles become stiff and rigid immediately after death. For example, in case of death due to drowning, if the person grabs hold of grass, then immediately after death, he would be having a clenched fist with some grass in it. On the contrary rigor mortis occurs in all the body muscles gradually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts of the body based on the position at the time of death. In drowning cases, it affects the face, neck, chest, and limbs, not just the lower limbs.

questions.text: A clinician is examining various approaches to determine the rate at which a contraceptive method fails. Which index is specifically employed for this purpose? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Pearl index

 

  • Pearl index is the common method used to measure contraceptive failure rate.
  • It is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). This rate is given by the formula:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharmacological index: This term is generally refers to the study and categorization of drugs based on their effects and properties.

 

Option C. Performance index: This may refer to various metrics used to evaluate the performance of processes or systems in different fields.

 

Option D. Efficacy index: While this might be used to measure the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods

choices.text: To break AT bonds high Tm is required
To break GC bonds low Tm is required
To break AT bonds low Tm is required
AT bonds and GC bonds need the same TM

questions.text: Which of the following is true? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To break AT bonds low Tm is required

 

To break AT bonds low Tm is required: This statement is correct. AT bonds are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are relatively weak compared to GC bonds. Therefore, lower temperatures (low Tm) are required to break AT bonds, causing the DNA to denature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To break AT bonds high Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. The melting temperature (Tm) of DNA is the temperature at which the double-stranded DNA molecule begins to denature or separate into single strands. AT bonds (adenine-thymine) are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are weaker than the three hydrogen bonds holding GC bonds (guanine-cytosine) together. Therefore, lower temperatures (relatively low Tm) are required to break AT bonds.

 

Option B. To break GC bonds low Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. GC bonds have a higher Tm compared to AT bonds because they are held together by three hydrogen bonds, making them more stable. So, higher temperatures (relatively high Tm) are required to break GC bonds.

 

Option D. AT bonds and GC bonds need the same Tm: This statement is incorrect. As explained above, AT bonds and GC bonds have different Tm values due to the difference in the number of hydrogen bonds holding them together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, there are two hydrogen bonds between A and T and three hydrogen bonds between G and C. So, AT bonds will require a lower Tm (melting temperature) compared to GC bonds as less energy is required for breaking 2 bonds compared to three bonds.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

 

The patient with given complaints points to meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae and it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus colonies. When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus.

 

H. influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided

 

When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, then factor V is released from S. aureus.

 

It forms larger colonies adjacent to S. aureus streak line and size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line, this is known as Satellitism. Therefore, used for the isolation of H. influenzae.

 

 

 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

 

  1. Factor X = hemin→ present freely in blood
  2. Factor V = Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) →present inside RBCs (also produced by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus)

 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and less commonly suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis.

 

DOC - Cefotaxime or ceftazidime

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bacitracin sensitive: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram positive coccus.

 

Option B. Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar: Associated with organisms such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Proteus species.

 

Option D. It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar: Alpha-hemolysis on blood agar is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumonia, a gram-positive coccus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Haemophilus influenzae infection, particularly meningitis, look for satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, indicating the organism's dependence on externally sourced V factor for growth.

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

questions.text: Which chromosome is involved in myotonic dystrophy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromosome 19

 

Myotonic dystrophy is an inherited genetic disorder that affects muscle function. It is caused by an abnormal expansion of nucleotide repeats in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19.

 

Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is a type of muscular dystrophy, a group of genetic disorders that cause progressive muscle loss and weakness. In DM, muscles are often unable to relax after contraction. Other manifestations may include cataracts, intellectual disability and heart conduction problems. In men, there may be early balding and an inability to father children. While myotonic dystrophy can occur at any age, onset is typically in the 20s and 30s.

 

There is no cure. Treatments may include braces or wheelchairs, pacemakers and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation. The medications mexiletine or carbamazepine can help relax muscles. Pain, if it occurs, may be treated with tricyclic antidepressants and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chromosome 20, Option C. Chromosome 21 and Option D. Chromosome 22: These chromosomes are not associated with the mutation causing myotonic dystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myotonic dystrophy is linked to a mutation in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19, leading to diverse symptoms including muscle dysfunction, cataracts, and cardiac issues.

questions.text: This condition is treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

 

The condition shown in the image is pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "three Ds" of pellagra. Pellagra is caused by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) or its precursor, tryptophan. Nicotinamide is the form of niacin that is typically used in supplementation to treat pellagra. Niacin supplementation helps replenish the body's stores of this essential nutrient and alleviates the symptoms associated with the deficiency. The hallmark sign in the image is the "casal necklace," a symmetrical, hyperpigmented rash around the neck, which is typical of pellagra.

 

Note –

 

If with this clinical scenario like Pellagra with an increase in xanthurenic acid in urine, it indicates that the niacin deficiency is likely due to a Vitamin B6 deficiency. In such cases, Vitamin B6 supplementation is recommended for the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency leads to symptoms such as night blindness and xerophthalmia, not the symptoms seen in pellagra.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E is an antioxidant and its deficiency is associated with neurological problems, but it is not related to the symptoms of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and petechiae, which is unrelated to the condition seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is treated with niacin or nicotinamide supplementation

questions.text: Which of the following can be mediated by CRISPR CAS 9 technology? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA editing

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is a powerful tool used for DNA editing. It works by creating double-strand breaks in the DNA at specific locations. The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats) component guides the Cas9 endonuclease to the precise cutting site within the genome. Once the DNA is cut, the cell’s natural repair mechanisms are used to add, delete, or replace genetic material at the targeted site, enabling precise editing of the DNA sequence.

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is derived from a natural immune system in bacteria, which uses this mechanism to defend against bacteriophages by cutting their DNA. In genetic engineering, this system has been harnessed for various applications, including gene deletion, exogenous gene insertion, and multigene editing, all of which involve altering the DNA sequence in a targeted manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA replication: CRISPR-Cas9 does not play a role in DNA replication, which is the process by which DNA is copied before cell division. DNA replication is managed by other cellular machinery, including DNA polymerases.

 

Option B. Post-transcriptional modification: This involves changes to RNA after it has been transcribed from DNA, such as splicing, editing, or polyadenylation. CRISPR-Cas9 does not mediate these processes; it specifically targets DNA.

 

Option C. DNA induction: This term is not commonly used in the context of molecular biology, and it does not apply to CRISPR-Cas9 technology. CRISPR-Cas9 is specifically used for editing DNA, not for inducing or initiating processes within the DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is primarily used for precise DNA editing, enabling targeted modifications to the genetic code

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss. He has hypoglycemia and elevated alpha fetoprotein levels (250IU) but has normal AST and ALT. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

A history of chronic alcohol intake with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss is suggestive of a liver dysfunction.  

 

 

Other Options:

 

Differential Diagnosis:

 

Option A. Liver cirrhosis: Often has elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and may present with similar symptoms but is not typically associated with high AFP levels.

 

Option B. Hepatitis: Would show elevated AST and ALT levels, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Cholangiocarcinoma: May present with jaundice and weight loss but is not typically associated with elevated AFP levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma should be considered in a chronic alcoholic presenting with abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, hypoglycemia, and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, especially with normal AST and ALT levels.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Methemoglobinemia

 

The patient presenting with a brownish hue in the blood, coupled with a history of chronic stable angina, points towards methemoglobinemia. Patients with chronic stable angina are often on nitrate therapy, which is a known risk factor for developing methemoglobinemia.

 

Methemoglobinemia occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe²⁺) state to the ferric (Fe³⁺) state, which is unable to bind oxygen effectively. This results in reduced oxygen delivery to tissues, leading to symptoms such as fatigue and cyanosis. The brownish hue of the blood, often described as chocolate-colored, is characteristic of methemoglobinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxyhemoglobinemia: Carboxyhemoglobinemia is caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, typically associated with exposure to fire or automobile exhaust. The blood in this condition has a cherry red color, not brownish.

 

Option B. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is a form of anemia where the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells. It does not cause a brownish hue in the blood.

 

Option D. Sulfhemoglobinemia: Sulfhemoglobinemia results from the incorporation of sulfur into hemoglobin, leading to a greenish or bluish color of the blood, rather than brownish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A brownish hue in the blood, especially in a patient on nitrate therapy, is indicative of methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized, impairing its ability to carry oxygen effectively.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors, and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye finding is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wilson’s disease

 

The most probable diagnosis for this patient, based on the clinical presentation and the image showing icterus in the eyes, is Wilson's disease. Wilson's disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which leads to abnormal copper metabolism. This results in copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, cornea, and kidneys.

 

The presence of intentional tremors, poor scholastic performance, and hepatomegaly are consistent with Wilson's disease. The eye finding likely represents a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, a characteristic feature of Wilson's disease. The KF ring is a brownish or golden ring around the cornea, which is caused by copper deposition in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington's chorea: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance. It is characterized by involuntary movements (chorea), cognitive decline, and psychiatric disturbances. Unlike Wilson's disease, Huntington's chorea does not typically present with hepatomegaly or KF rings.

 

Option C. Glutaric aciduria: Glutaric aciduria is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder that usually presents in the first 6 months of life. Clinical features include hypotonia, jitteriness, and progressive hyperkinetic movements (dystonia, choreoathetosis). This disorder does not present with the eye findings seen in the image or the liver involvement typical of Wilson's disease.

 

Option D. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A is a viral infection transmitted primarily through the fecal-oral route. It typically presents with symptoms such as jaundice, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever. However, it does not cause the neurological symptoms, intentional tremors, or KF rings seen in Wilson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's disease is characterized by the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings, hepatomegaly, neurological symptoms (such as intentional tremors), and is diagnosed with decreased serum ceruloplasmin, increased 24-hour urinary copper excretion, and the presence of KF rings.

choices.text: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.text: Myasthenia gravis is associated with: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies target and destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This impairs the ability of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine to stimulate muscle contractions, leading to decreased synaptic transmission. The disease is characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly worsening with activity and improving with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased myosin: This option is not related to myasthenia gravis, which primarily affects the neurotransmitter receptors, not the muscle fiber proteins like myosin.

 

Option B. Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: While decreased acetylcholine release can affect neuromuscular function, in myasthenia gravis, the principal issue is the reduced effectiveness of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction due to antibody-mediated receptor damage, not a reduction in its release. Occurs with pre-synaptic blockers like bungarotoxin of krait causing reduced release of Ach rendering neostigmine ineffective.

 

Option C. Absence of troponin C: This is unrelated to the pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis. Troponin C is involved in the regulation of muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle, not neurotransmitter release or receptor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune disease characterized by Ab to postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Hence, treated with steroids and immunomodulators.

questions.text: In seat belt injury, the most commonly involved organ is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus

 

Explanation:

 

Seat belts are known to decrease mortality and prevent head injuries in accidents. However, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries.

 

Among all the thoracic and abdominal injuries associated with seat belt use, the maximum damage occurs to three organs: mesentery, omentum, and bowel (hollow viscus). This combination of injuries is known as the "seat belt syndrome." Therefore, the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injury is the hollow viscus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Liver + Spleen: Although liver and spleen injuries can occur in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly involved organs compared to the hollow viscus.

 

Option. B. Lungs: While thoracic injuries can be increased due to seat belt use, the lungs are not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries.

 

Option. C. Head of Pancreas: The head of the pancreas is not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries compared to the hollow viscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In seat belt injuries, the most commonly involved organ is the hollow viscus (bowel), along with the mesentery and omentum, constituting the "seat belt syndrome." Although seat belts are protective and prevent head injuries, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries, with the hollow viscus being the most frequently affected.

questions.text: In a prolonged intubation patient, the following is seen. Staging for this is given by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cotton Meyer

 

The images depict subglottic stenosis, which is a narrowing of the airway below the vocal cords, often due to prolonged intubation. This condition results from the high-pressure cuff of the endotracheal tube irritating the mucosa beneath the glottis. The Cotton Meyer classification system is used to stage subglottic stenosis based on the degree of airway narrowing:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radkowski: This staging system is used for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), not subglottic stenosis.

 

Option C. AJCC: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging is primarily used for cancer staging and does not apply to subglottic stenosis.

 

Option D. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for categorizing the extent of cancers, specifically focusing on tumor size (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M). It is not relevant for subglottic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Subglottic stenosis resulting from prolonged intubation is staged using the Cotton Meyer classification, which grades the severity based on the percentage of airway narrowing

 

  • Grade 1: 0-50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: 100% stenosis (complete obstruction)

questions.text: An adult patient presents with tall stature, pigeon chest deformity, long arm span, lens dislocation, and cardiac defects. This patient is likely to have a defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibrillin

 

The clinical presentation described is strongly suggests Marfan syndrome, a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue.

 

Marfan syndrome is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the formation of elastic fibers in connective tissue. Features of Marfan syndrome include tall stature, long arms, pigeon chest (pectus carinatum), lens dislocation (typically upward and temporal), and cardiac defects such as aortic aneurysm and mitral valve prolapse. The defect in fibrillin leads to the characteristic physical and systemic manifestations of the syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elastase: Elastase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of elastin and is associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, leading to conditions like emphysema. It is not related to Marfan syndrome.

 

Option C. Collagen: Collagen defects are associated with other connective tissue disorders, such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Alport syndrome. Collagen abnormalities do not explain the specific features of Marfan syndrome.

 

Option D. Laminin: Laminin is a major glycoprotein in the extracellular matrix, playing a key role in cell adhesion and structural integrity of tissues. It is not associated with Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan syndrome is characterized by a defect in fibrillin-1 due to mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to tall stature, skeletal deformities, lens dislocation, and cardiovascular abnormalities.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. His HRCT thorax is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

 

In patients with HIV and respiratory failure, findings of GGO & cysts within GGO in perihilar locations on HRCT are characteristic for PCP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcal pneumonia: This typically presents with more localized consolidations or cavitary lesions rather than the diffuse, bilateral ground-glass opacities seen in PCP.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal pneumonia: Often manifests as lobar consolidation, which does not match the diffuse pattern observed in the HRCT.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: In HIV-positive patients, tuberculosis may present in various forms including miliary patterns or cavitary disease, especially if the CD4 count is low, but the diffuse ground-glass appearance is more characteristic of PCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Opportunistic Infection in HIV/Chap

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

 

Chest X-ray image describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

 

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot ("Coeur-en sabot").
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egg on side appearance: Egg on string appearance is seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA)

 

Option C. Egg on string appearance: Scimitar sign is seen in Scimitar syndrome which is also known as partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

 

Option D. Snowman sign: Snowman sign is seen in supracardiac TAPVC

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

questions.text: The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) COPD

 

In the provided spirometry graph, the normal and abnormal curves represent volumes and flow rates during forced expiration.

 

The abnormal graph is indicative of COPD, as it shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a decrease in FEV1 with a more preserved FVC, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is consistent with the abnormal curve in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: This condition where the walls of airways (bronchi) widen and are thickened from inflammation. It can cause obstructive lung changes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is often normal or less dramatically reduced than in COPD. The spirometry curve will not show the same pattern as shown in graph.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is a restrictive lung disease, typically showing a reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, unlike the pattern shown for the diseased lung in the graph.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: As a restrictive disease, pulmonary fibrosis would typically show a decrease in lung volumes (including FVC) with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, which differs from the obstructive pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spirometry pattern for COPD shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is indicative of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: A patient feels that someone is inserting some thoughts in his mind. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delusion of influence

 

The patient's experience of someone inserting thoughts into their mind is best described as thought insertion, a type of delusion where an individual believes that external forces are controlling their thoughts. This phenomenon falls under the category of delusion of influence, where a person feels that their thoughts, feelings, or actions are being controlled or influenced by an external source. This is also known as a passivity phenomenon, where the individual feels passive and controlled by others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nihilistic delusion: This involves a belief that oneself, others, or the world does not exist or is coming to an end. For example, a patient might believe their internal organs are rotten or that the world has stopped.

 

Option C. Othello syndrome: This is a delusional belief of infidelity, where the patient is convinced that their partner is unfaithful.

 

Option D. Delusion of reference: This involves the belief that common elements of the environment are directly related to the individual, such as thinking people are talking about them or that events are directed at them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A delusion of influence involves the belief that an external force is controlling one's thoughts, feelings, or actions. This phenomenon is also known as thought insertion or passivity phenomenon.

questions.text: In a given population, total births in a year are 4050. There are 50 stillbirths. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, whereas the number of deaths within 8-28 days of life is 150. What is the neonatal mortality rate in the population?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 50

 

Explanation:

 

The neonatal mortality rate is calculated by dividing the total number of neonatal deaths (deaths within 0-28 days of life) by the total number of live births and multiplying the result by 1,000.

 

Given:

 

  • Total births in a year = 4050
  • Stillbirths = 50
  • Neonatal deaths within the first 7 days (early neonatal period) = 50
  • Neonatal deaths within 8-28 days (late neonatal period) = 150

 

Step 1: Calculate the number of live births.

Number of live births = Total births - Stillbirths

Number of live births = 4050 - 50 = 4000

 

Step 2: Calculate the total number of neonatal deaths.

Total neonatal deaths = Neonatal deaths within the first 7 days + Neonatal deaths within 8-28 days

Total neonatal deaths = 50 + 150 = 200

 

Step 3: Calculate the neonatal mortality rate using the formula:

Neonatal mortality rate = (Total neonatal deaths / Total live births) × 1000

Neonatal mortality rate = (200 / 4000) × 1000

Neonatal mortality rate = 50 per 1,000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neonatal mortality rate is a crucial indicator that represents the number of neonatal deaths (deaths within 0-28 days of life) per 1,000 live births in a given population. It encompasses both early neonatal deaths (within the first 7 days) and late neonatal deaths (8-28 days).

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of death in cold water drowning? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vagal inhibition

 

  • In cold water drowning cause of death is Cold shock response/ hydrocution / immersion syndrome.
  • It is a series of neurogenic cardio-respiratory responses caused by sudden immersion in cold water.
  • Death results from vagal inhibition of the heart, i.e., cardiac arrest occurring due to increased stimulation of the vagus nerve by
  • Sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx
  • Diving into the water in a manner that is suddenly strikes the abdomen
  • Sudden in-rush of cold water into the ears

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asphyxia: Common in other types of drowning but not the primary cause in cold water drowning.

 

Option B. Laryngeal spasm: Can contribute to asphyxia but is not the primary mechanism in cold water drowning.

 

Option D. Cardiac arrest: While cardiac arrest occurs, it is due to vagal inhibition, not directly from cold water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cold water drowning, the primary cause of death is vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest due to the sudden stimulation of the vagus nerve from cold water immersion.

questions.text: A patient had a history of TIA and was admitted. 48 hours later he developed severe respiratory difficulty and fever. What is the probable cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hospital Acquired Pneumonia

 

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia that occurs 48 hours or more after admission to a hospital and was not present at the time of admission. In this case, the patient developed severe respiratory difficulty and fever 48 hours after being admitted, which fits the definition of HAP. This type of pneumonia is typically caused by bacteria that are more resistant to antibiotics compared to those causing community-acquired pneumonia. Early identification and treatment are crucial for better outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): ARDS can cause severe respiratory difficulty and is often associated with significant illnesses or injuries, but the timeline and presence of fever in this case are more consistent with an infection like pneumonia.

 

Option C. Community Acquired Pneumonia: This type of pneumonia occurs outside of a healthcare setting or within 48 hours of hospital admission. Given that the symptoms developed 48 hours after admission, it is not classified as community-acquired.

 

Option D. Aspiration Pneumonia: Aspiration pneumonia occurs when food, liquid, or vomit is inhaled into the lungs, leading to infection. While it can occur in hospitalized patients, the timing and presentation in this case are more suggestive of hospital-acquired pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumonia developing 48 hours or more after hospital admission is classified as hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman whose last delivery was 5 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea of 2 years. She does not bleed on giving estrogen and progesterone. A laparoscopy shows the following. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genital TB

 

The patient presents with secondary amenorrhea for two years and does not bleed when given estrogen and progesterone, indicating that the problem lies in the endometrium. The destruction of the endometrium can occur due to two main conditions: Asherman's syndrome and genital tuberculosis.

 

  • Asherman's syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions typically following a vigorous dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • Genital tuberculosis, however, causes chronic endometritis, leading to the destruction of the endometrium and the absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. The laparoscopy shows whitish caseating lesions on the surface of the uterus, which are characteristic of genital tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly causing pelvic pain and infertility. It does not typically result in secondary amenorrhea or the absence of bleeding on hormone administration, and it does not produce the characteristic whitish lesions seen in the laparoscopy.

 

Option B. Fibroids: Uterine fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can cause menorrhagia, pelvic pressure, and pain but do not lead to secondary amenorrhea or absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. Fibroids also do not present with caseating lesions.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that rarely affects the genital tract. It does not cause endometrial destruction, secondary amenorrhea, or the absence of withdrawal bleeding when given hormones, nor does it produce the characteristic uterine lesions seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis can cause chronic endometritis and endometrial destruction, leading to secondary amenorrhea and absence of withdrawal bleeding on hormone administration, with characteristic whitish caseating lesions visible on laparoscopy.

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

 

The identification of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as the causative agent in this case of tinea capitis is confirmed by the positive hair perforation test. This test is particularly valuable for differentiating between species of Trichophyton, as it assesses the fungus's ability to penetrate and degrade hair keratin.

 

  • Hair Perforation Test: This diagnostic tool is used to differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from Trichophyton rubrum, as T. mentagrophytes demonstrates the ability to perforate hair, causing surface erosion which gives a wedge-shaped appearance to the hair shaft. This is a key characteristic that helps in identifying the fungal species responsible for the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not typically infect hair, more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Option B. Microsporum audouinii: Causes tinea capitis but does not show a positive result on the hair perforation test.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum: Another cause of tinea capitis but also does not typically show a positive hair perforation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: A child with Celiac disease can be given: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rice


Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, rye, and oats (referred to by the mnemonic "BROW"). Individuals with celiac disease must strictly avoid these grains and any foods containing gluten.

 

Rice is naturally gluten-free and is safe for individuals with celiac disease. It is a staple food that can be consumed without concern for gluten contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sooji: Sooji, also known as semolina, is made from wheat and contains gluten, making it unsuitable for someone with celiac disease.

 

Option C. Oat: Oats can be contaminated with gluten during processing, and even gluten-free oats might not be well tolerated by all individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, oats are generally avoided unless they are certified gluten-free and tolerated by the patient.

 

Option D. Broken wheat/daliya: Broken wheat, also known as daliya, is another form of wheat and contains gluten, making it unsuitable for individuals with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:


Celiac patients must avoid gluten-containing grains like barley, rye, oats, and wheat (BROW). Rice is a safe and gluten-free option for these patients.

questions.text: A patient presented with redness and extreme pain in the eye. There is also diminution of vision and discharge after the use of contact lenses. Which organism can be the causative agent here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthamoeba

 

Acanthamoeba is a protozoan that commonly infects the cornea, particularly in individuals who misuse contact lenses. It is characterized by severe pain that is disproportionate to the clinical signs observed. This is due to the organism’s tendency to infiltrate perineurally, causing intense pain by involving the corneal nerves.

 

Acanthamoeba keratitis often presents with a ring-shaped corneal ulcer, which is a key diagnostic feature.

 

 

The culture medium is non-nutrient agar enriched with E. coli.

 

The condition is serious and can lead to severe visual impairment if not treated promptly with appropriate anti-amoebic medications such as Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) or Propamidine isethionate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria: Listeria primarily causes systemic infections and is not typically associated with eye infections or contact lens misuse. It is a less common cause of keratitis and does not present with the severe pain characteristic of Acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of bacterial keratitis, often presenting with redness, discharge, and visual impairment. However, it does not cause the extreme pain seen in Acanthamoeba infections, as it does not infiltrate nerves.

 

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is a bacterial pathogen that can cause various infections but is not commonly associated with severe pain and the distinct ring-shaped ulcer seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain that exceeds clinical findings and is often associated with contact lens misuse, presenting with a distinctive ring-shaped corneal ulcer.

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV

 

The questions is related to genetic material of different organisms or viruses and their base pairing rules. In DNA, adenine (A) always pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). However, in RNA, which is the genetic material of some viruses like HIV, thymine is replaced by uracil (U) in base pairing. So, in RNA, adenine pairs with uracil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli (Escherichia coli): E. coli is a bacterium, and its genetic material is DNA. In DNA, adenine pairs with thymine, so the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option B. Mitochondrial DNA of humans: Mitochondrial DNA is also composed of DNA, and in DNA, adenine pairs with thymine. Therefore, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have dsDNA as their genetic material, so adenine pairs with thymine in their DNA. Thus, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

questions.text: What is the compression to ventilation ratio in an adult cardiac arrest patient in the presence of more than one rescuer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult patients experiencing cardiac arrest, the recommended compression to ventilation ratio during CPR is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers present. This ratio ensures that adequate chest compressions are delivered to maintain blood circulation while allowing time for sufficient ventilation to oxygenate the blood. The priority in adult CPR is effective chest compressions, which is why the ratio is set to 30 compressions for every 2 ventilations.

 

This ratio remains constant irrespective of whether there is one rescuer or more than one, ensuring consistency and simplicity during the resuscitation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For adult CPR, regardless of the number of rescuers, the compression to ventilation ratio should always be 30:2 to ensure effective circulation and oxygenation during cardiac arrest.

 

Additionally, For children with one rescuer, the ratio is 30 compressions to 2 ventilations (30:2); with two rescuers, the ratio is 15 compressions to 2 ventilations (15:2). For neonates, the ratio is 3 compressions to 1 ventilation (3:1).

questions.text: Most potent biological Estrogen: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estradiol

 

Explanation:

 

Estrogens are a group of steroid hormones that play a crucial role in the regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the different forms of estrogen, estradiol (E2) is the most potent and biologically active. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the dominant form of estrogen during the reproductive years.

 

Estradiol binds with the highest affinity to estrogen receptors compared to other forms like estrone and estriol, which is why it exerts the most potent biological effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrone: Estrone (E1) is less potent than estradiol and is the primary form of estrogen after menopause. It has a weaker affinity for estrogen receptors and thus, exerts less biological activity.

 

Option C. Estriol: Estriol (E3) is the weakest of the three primary estrogens. It is primarily produced during pregnancy and has the least biological activity due to its low affinity for estrogen receptors.

 

Option D. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogens are a mixture of several types of estrogens, typically used in hormone replacement therapy. They are not as biologically potent as estradiol when considered individually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent biological estrogen.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchi

 

Among the given options, bronchi (medium-sized airway) offer maximum resistance.

 

The best answer here is bronchi, as the other options suggest smaller airways and bronchi is the only medium-sized airway.

 

Since the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series, smallest airway contributes little to overall resistance. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases because the total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high resulting in less resistance. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially because the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

 

Other factors affecting airway resistance:

 

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the trans airway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar duct and C. Respiratory bronchioles: These smaller airways have much lower resistance due to their large total cross-sectional area, which reduces resistance despite their small individual diameters.

 

Option D. Small bronchioles: Similar to the respiratory bronchioles, their high number and extensive branching reduce overall resistance.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bronchi, the medium-sized airways, have the highest airway resistance due to their relatively narrow diameter compared to the total cross-sectional area of smaller airways.

 

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula:

 

 

Where:

 

  • R is the resistance
  • is pie symbol
  • r is radius
  • is viscosity
  • L is length

 

According to Poisuille’s formula, Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power radius.

 

Poiseuille- Hagen formula suggests that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance.

choices.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance
Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance
Creatinine is equal to inulin clearance

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Creatinine clearance? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance

 

  • Creatinine clearance is often used as a measure of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) but it is important to note that it slightly overestimates GFR. This overestimation is because creatinine is not only filtered by the glomerulus but also secreted in small amounts by the renal tubules. Therefore, creatinine clearance is typically greater than inulin clearance.
  • Inulin clearance, on the other hand, is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR. Inulin is a polysaccharide that is freely filtered by the kidneys but neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules. Thus, it provides an accurate measure of the filtration capacity of the kidneys.

 

Clinical Relevance

 

  • Inulin clearance is an accurate measure but is seldom used in clinical practice due to the complexity and cost of the procedure.
  • Creatinine clearance, despite its limitations, is commonly used because it is simpler and cheaper to measure. It requires only serum and urine creatinine levels, making it practical for routine medical evaluations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance: Incorrect because creatinine clearance slightly overestimates GFR due to additional renal tubular secretion.

 

Option C. Creatinine clearance is equal to inulin clearance: Incorrect because the secretion of creatinine leads to higher clearance values compared to inulin.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as option B correctly describes the relationship between creatinine and inulin clearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatinine clearance is commonly used to estimate GFR but it is greater than inulin clearance due to slight secretion of creatinine by the renal tubules. In contrast, inulin clearance, being neither secreted nor reabsorbed, provides a more accurate measurement of renal filtration function.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given structure: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IV

 

Explanation:

 

In the given image, the dorsal aspect of the brainstem is marked and the cranial nerve that is passing there is the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

 

Trochlear nerve

 

  • Origin : The trochlear nerve is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal (posterior) aspect of the brain. Specifically, it originates from the dorsal surface of the midbrain, below the inferior colliculus.
  • Exit proceed to the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbit.
  • Function: It is a motor nerve that innervates a single extraocular muscle, the superior oblique muscle. The primary action of the superior oblique muscle is to intort (rotate inward), depress, and abduct the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III):

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Facial Nerve (VII):

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.
     

Option D. Abducens Nerve (VI):

 

  • Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.
  • Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve that originates in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus from the trochlear nuclei. It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the brainstem's dorsal surface and has the longest intracranial course.

 

The main actions of superior oblique are:

 

  • Depression in adducted position- Patients with trochlear nerve palsy have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in the adducted position.
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion of the eyeball.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Neurosecretory bodies except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adrenal cortical tumor

 

Neurosecretory bodies are not seen in adrenal cortical tumors.

 

Adrenocortical neoplasms produce aldosterone. Primary hyperaldosteronism due to a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma is Conn syndrome.

 

Microscopically, aldosterone-producing adenomas show spironolactone bodies which are eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions found after treatment with spironolactone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C-cells, which are neuroendocrine cells. These cells secrete calcitonin and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Option B. Pituitary adenoma: Pituitary adenomas are tumors of the pituitary gland, many of which are neuroendocrine in nature. They can produce hormones such as prolactin, growth hormone, or ACTH, and neurosecretory granules can be found in these tumors.

 

Option C. Paraganglioma: Paragangliomas are tumors that arise from paraganglia, which are collections of neuroendocrine cells. These cells are closely related to the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems and often contain neurosecretory granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurosecretory bodies are associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but not with adrenal cortical tumors, which originate from the adrenal cortex and are involved in steroid hormone production.

 

Tumors associated with neurosecretory granules
